pageData.text: Cell division is necessary for growth, cell replacement, and asexual reproduction. In sexually reproducing organisms, a special form of cell division occurs in the production of sex cells, or gametes. This investigation introduces the fundamentals of cell division and some of the mechanisms cells use to control the process. Furthermore, this unit introduces the processes involved in producing sex cells, gametes, and some of the consequences resulting from errors during the production of gametes.

Cellular events are modeled in this chromosome-simulation activity. Pop beads are used to visualize and understand the organization and segregation of chromosomes during cell division. The regulated steps of mitosis and meiosis are explored in the first part of the series, and then abnormalities, such as nondisjunction and aneuploidy, are examined.

pageData.text: In the United States, most hospitals routinely screen newborns for genetic disorders. In each state, lawmakers determine what diseases and disorders will be screened for and who will cover the cost of these tests. Newborn genetic screening programs have been implemented to identify treatable genetic disorders quickly. The outcomes of many of these disorders are much better when treatments are started as soon as possible. Without treatment, many of these disorders can result in a lifetime of disability.

Fear and confusion often occur when a doctor tells a parent that their newborn child has a genetic disorder. Genetic counselors are healthcare professionals who are trained to help parents understand genetic test results. Genetic testing can be a powerful and life-saving tool, but there is still a lot that is not understood about how genetic disorders may impact an individual or a family. Genetic counselors work closely with doctors and families to help the families understand the diagnosis. They may also act as an advocate and help families find resources and treatments.

pageData.text: Mitosis and meiosis are the means by which genetic information (DNA), which is packaged in threadlike structures called chromosomes, is passed from one generation of cells to the next. In mitosis, the nucleus of a diploid cell (containing replicated chromosomes) divides. The result of mitosis is two cells that are genetically identical, with the same (diploid) number of chromosomes as the parent cell. In meiosis, the nucleus of a diploid cell, containing replicated chromosomes, divides twice. Genetic information is exchanged between homologous chromosomes. The result of meiosis is four genetically diverse haploid cells, called gametes, each possessing half the number of chromosomes as those in the parent cell.

In terms of the life of a cell, reproduction is a crucial, but relatively brief, part of an ongoing process known as the cell cycle. The longer period between cell divisions is called interphase (Figure 1). During interphase, the cell grows, replicates its chromosomes, and produces and assembles the cellular structures needed for cell division.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Diagram of the phases of Mitosis. Interphase is made up of G1, S, and G2 phases while Mitosis consists of Prophase, Metaphase, Anaphase, and Telophase.

pageData.text: Mitosis is the division of the nuclear material within a somatic cell (any cell not designed for sexual reproduction) and is the first step of cellular division by which one parent cell divides, creating two genetically identical daughter cells. This form of cellular reproduction ensures that the daughter cells produced by the parent cell contain genetic material identical to that of the parent cell.

The names of the stages of meiosis and some of the processes involved are similar to those in mitosis, but meiosis has a dramatically different purpose. Meiosis results in gametes, cells designed for sexual reproduction, and containing half the number of chromosomes of the original cell.

pageData.subTitle: Cell Cycle: Interphase
pageData.text: Interphase occurs before mitosis as a preparation for nuclear division. It is the longest stage of the cell cycle, and is composed of three sub-phases. During this time, DNA is replicated, the cell rapidly grows and produces organelles, and proteins are created. The nuclear membrane and nucleolus are distinct. (or gap phase 1) is characterized by cell growth and the synthesis of mRNA and proteins. Cytokinins and growth factors are classes of molecules, which can promote cell growth and division. Each stage of cell division is highly regulated. Checkpoints are regulatory points in eukaryotic cells where checkpoint proteins determine if conditions are favorable to divide.

At the , proteins check for DNA damage. In the event of damage detection, chemical pathways are triggered, which inhibit the activation of proteins that advance the cell into . If no damage is detected, then the cell proceeds past the and the cell will enter S-phase, during which the DNA is replicated forming identical sister chromatids. These chromatids remain joined to each other at the . The centromere is a region of DNA where a potein complex called a kinetochore is assembled to bind the two chromatids together. Following the S-phase, the cell enters (gap phase II). Here the cell prepares for division by synthesizing the proteins necessary for chromosome sorting and cell division. During the G2-phase, the second regulatory checkpoint, the occurs. The replicated DNA is checked for errors, and the quantity of proteins is monitored. If no errors are found, the follows. This is where mitosis begins.

pageData.subTitle: Cell Cycle: Mitosis
pageData.text: Prophase (Figure 2) is the first phase of mitosis. During this phase, replicated DNA condenses into chromosomes that consist of two identical sister chromatids bound by a <button class='glossary-text'>centromere</button>. The nuclear membrane begins to disappear as it breaks down. In animal cells, tubular structures called <button class='glossary-text'>centrioles</button>, are located on opposite sides of the cell. In later phases, microtubules radiating from the centrioles will attach to each side of the centromere and pull the sister chromatids apart. Most plants and fungi have evolved different mechanisms to organize their spindle fibers.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: A micrograph of an animal cell in prophase.

pageData.text: Metaphase (Figure 3) is the shortest phase of mitosis. During this phase, the nuclear membrane has completely disappeared. Microtubules radiating from opposite sides of the cell have attached to the centromeres of the chromosomes, forming the spindle apparatus. Chromosomes line up along the equator of the cell. The final check-point, the <button class='glossary-text'>metaphase checkpoint</button> ensures that the spindle apparatus is connected correctly. If it is not, mitosis will stop until corrections are made.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A micrograph of an animal cell in metaphase.

pageData.text: During anaphase, (Figure 4) the microtubules pull sister chromatids toward opposite sides of the cell. Each chromatid is now properly referred to as a chromosome. The cell now has twice the original number of chromosomes. This segregation results in two regions of compact chromosomes that are genetically identical.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: A micrograph of an animal cell in anaphase.

pageData.text: As telophase (Figure 5) begins, a visible nuclear membrane begins to form around each set of chromosomes. The chromosomes decondense. The nucleoli form in each nucleus, and the microtubules break down.

Cytokinesis is the division of the cytoplasm and its contents into two daughter cells. This stage of the cell cycle may occur at the same time as telophase of mitosis. Cytokinesis in plant and animal cells occurs by different mechanisms. Plant cells develop a cell plate along the equatorial plane outward to the cell wall to divide the cell; new cell walls form along the cell plate. In animal cells, microfilaments form around the cell and contract, forming an indentation called a cleavage furrow. Eventually, the parent cell is pinched into two daughter cells.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: A micrograph of an animal cell in telophase.

pageData.subTitle: Meiosis
pageData.text: Meiosis (Figure 6) is a similar process to mitosis, and many of the steps are similar, but the function and outcome of meiosis is very different. Meiosis occurs in germ cells (sex cells) and involves two sequential divisions, called meiosis I and meiosis II. Each nucleus resulting from meiotic division is haploid, meaning that it contains half the number of chromosomes as the parent. These haploid cells are critical in the process of sexual reproduction. They are genetically distinct from one another, and allow for the recombination of traits that evolution acts upon. Without the halving of chromosome number, which takes place during meiosis, the number of chromosomes in each cell would increase exponentially with each generation.

Interphase, the longest stage of the process, occurs before meiosis, as a preparation for nuclear division. During this time, DNA is replicated, and the cell rapidly grows and produces organelles. The nuclear membrane and nucleolus are distinct. The nucleolus consists of nucleic acids and proteins.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Diagram of meiosis.

pageData.text: In prophase I, the chromosomes condense and the nuclear membrane breaks down and disappears. Microtubules attach to the chromosomes, pulling homologs together to form a <button class='glossary-text'>bivalent or tetrad</button>. This process is called <button class='glossary-text'>synapsis</button>. The homologs can then exchange genetic information in a process called <button class='glossary-text'>crossing-over</button>. Crossing-over occurs when sections of DNA are traded between non-sister chromatids of a homologous pair. This allows for greater genetic variation between daughter cells.

As metaphase I starts, the nuclear membrane has completely disappeared. Microtubules radiating from opposite sides of the cell line up homologous pairs along the equator of the cell. Two pairs of sister chromatids line up side-by-side. The way that the homologs of a pair line up along the equator is random. Random assortment is important since it generates greater genetic variation between daughter cells. Chromosome number varies by species. The number of random alignments possible equals 2<sup>n</sup>, where n equals the number of chromosome pairs in a diploid cell.

Using the formula above, we can calculate the number of random alignments possible for different species. Humans have 23 pairs of chromosomes so the number of random alignments equals 2<sup>23</sup>=8,388,608. Dogs on the other hand have 39 pairs allowing for 2<sup>39</sup>=549,755,813,888 different possible alignments. The large number of chromosomes in dogs allows for a vastly greater number of possible combinations. Since genetic variation translates into variation within physical traits. This is largely responsible for the very great physical and genetic diversity found in dogs.

Anaphase I is characterized by homologous chromosomes being pulled toward opposite sides of the cell by microtubules. Note that sister chromatids are still held together by a , which is not the case in anaphase of mitosis.
A visible nuclear membrane begins to form around each set of chromosomes in telophase I. The chromosomes decondense, and the microtubules break down. These processes may vary somewhat by species.

Meiosis II begins after a brief interphase. DNA is not replicated, but the do duplicate before prophase II. The chromosomes of each cell condense, and the nuclear membranes break down. The chromosomes line up along the equator of each cell in metaphase II. During anaphase II, microtubules pull sister chromatids toward opposite sides of the cell. Each chromatid is now properly referred to as a chromosome.

Finally during telophase II a visible nuclear membrane begins to form around each set of chromosomes. The chromosomes decondense and the microtubules break down. Cytokinesis occurs during telophase II separating the two cells into four haploid cells.

pageData.subTitle: Chromosome Misregulation
pageData.text: Normally, mechanisms are in place to regulate the distribution of chromosomes in new cells as they divide. However, in such a complex process, errors can and do occur. Abnormalities in chromosomes number and structure result in a number of genetic disorders, and some current theories link chromosomal abnormalities to cancer.

Each somatic cell has 46 chromosomes in humans. The improper separation of chromosomes during meiosis, called nondisjunction, results in gametes that possess an unusual number of chromosomes. These cells are called <button class='glossary-text'>aneuploid</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Ploidy</button> refers to the number of chromosomes in a cell. Down syndrome, for example, is a result of possessing an extra chromosome 21. Down syndrome is also called Trisomy 21, indicating that there are three copies of chromosome 21.

Clear sufficient space on a desk, counter, or floor so that there is a flat surface measuring approximately 1 m x 1 m to conduct the modeling.
Read the Instruction Manual thoroughly and become familiar with the kit materials and activities before beginning.
Gather all additional supplies that are needed but not supplied.
In Activity 1, you will model the phases of mitosis.

Building two chromosomes (a homologous pair):
  • Make four strands containing 10 yellow beads each, and four strands containing 10 red beads each.
  • Connect two red strands to one magnetic to create a 20-bead strand with the centromere in the center. Each of these two strands is referred to as a chromosome arm.
  • Repeat Step 1b with the remaining strands of red beads.
  • Connect two yellow strands to one magnetic centromere to create a 20-bead strand with the centromere in the center.
  • Repeat Step 1d with the remaining strands of yellow beads.
  • Place the two long red strands together, and allow them to join at the magnetic centromeres.

This entire combined structure represents one chromosome. The materials representing chromatids in the activities described herein are only attracted to each other at the centromere, but in the cell, chromatids are associated throughout their length.
1. Allow the two long yellow strands to come together and join them at the magnetic centromeres.
This entire structure represents another chromosome, in this case, the homolog of the red chromosome. Together, the models represent a homologous pair of chromosomes.

Build a nuclear membrane:
  • Acquire six lengths of masking tape, each approximately 30 cm (1 ft) long.
  • Use the pieces of tape to create a closed circle on the surface of the desk or on the floor. The tape ring represents the nuclear membrane of the cell. The entire workspace represents the area inside the cell.
  • Place the two chromosomes inside the nuclear membrane.

Interphase:
  • Position two plastic centriole beads outside the nuclear membrane ring. Remember that each bead represents a pair of .
  • Position the two chromosomes in a pile inside the nuclear membrane.
  • Create a label using the tape and a wax pencil or marker for the stage in the mitotic cycle that reads “Interphase (Before Mitosis)” and position the label next to the nuclear membrane.
  • Take a photo of the model, including the label, with a digital camera or smartphone. This image will be used later for answering the Laboratory Questions, and the photo can also be used as a reminder for future test review.

A cell viewed under a microscope during interphase would not have distinguishable chromosomes because they are so long and thin. Chromosomes take on their characteristic “X” shape only when they are condensed.

Prophase:
  • Move the centrioles so that they are on opposite sides of the nucleus, approximately 20 cm from the outside edge of the nuclear membrane.
  • Use a piece of transparent tape to secure each centriole bead to the work surface so that the opening of the bead faces the area that was the nucleus.
  • Break down the nuclear membrane by pulling pieces of masking tape from the work surface. If possible, keep the masking tape in strips on the side of the workspace to reuse later as new nuclear membrane.
  • Arrange the chromosomes so that the arms are outstretched to demonstrate that they are condensed. Then, twist the arms of the sister chromatids so they are laying over one another.
  • Create a label for the stage in the mitotic cycle that reads “Mitosis Prophase,” and take a photo of the labeled model.

Metaphase:
  • Cut four lengths of thread, each approximately 1 meter long.
  • Using the four pieces of thread, tie a knot around each magnetic centromere. When finished, each chromatid should have a length of thread tied to it.
  • The threads represent microtubules that function to move the chromosomes around in the cell. Pass the loose end of each thread through the hole of a centriole bead, such that if the threads were pulled through the centriole beads, the two parts (chromatids) of the current chromosome would separate. See Figure 7.
  • Gently pull the threads from one chromosome through the centrioles so that the chromosome moves to the center, but the chromatids remain attached.
  • Pull the threads from the second chromosome to move it to the center also.
  • Create a label for this stage in the mitotic cycle that reads “Mitosis Metaphase,” and take a photo of the labeled model.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Homologous pairs lined up at the equator. Each homologous pair is made up of sister chromatids. Strings run from the centriole on the right side of the diagram to each of the centromeres of the right-hand chromatid. Other strings run from the left centriole to the centromeres of the left chromatids.

pageData.text: The two chromosomes should be roughly aligned between the centrioles. This action represents the chromosomes lining up along the metaphase plate.

Anaphase:
  • Pull the threads through the centriole beads until the chromatids separate.
  • Continue to separate the chromatids until they are adjacent to the centrioles. Each side of the cell should have one red and one yellow chromosome.
  • Create a label for this stage in the mitotic cycle that reads “Mitosis Anaphase,” and take a photo of the labeled model.

Telophase:
  • Remove the thread from each chromosome, and set aside the threads.
  • To represent decondensing, pile the chromosomes beside their closest centriole.
  • Use the masking tape previously set aside to create a new nuclear membrane around each set of chromosomes (or obtain more tape if necessary). This concludes the modeling of mitosis.
  • Create a label for this stage in the mitotic cycle that reads “Mitosis Telophase,” and take a photo of the labeled model.
  • Save the pieces of thread and the chromosome structures for the next activity.
Throughout the cell cycle, the centrioles are paired; the double centriole replicates as part of telophase. However, in these activities, each double centriole is represented by a single bead.
In Activity 2, you will model the phases of meiosis.

Build a nuclear membrane:
  • Use the saved tape to create a closed circle or hexagon shape on the surface of the desk or on a clear space on the floor. If necessary, obtain additional masking tape.
  • Allow the two red chromatids (from the previous activity) to come together at the magnetic . Repeat with the two yellow chromatids.
  • Place the red and yellow chromosomes inside the nuclear membrane.
The tape ring represents the nuclear membrane of the cell. The entire workspace represents the area inside the cell.

Interphase:
  • Position two plastic outside the nuclear membrane ring.
  • Position the chromosomes in a pile inside the nuclear membrane.
  • Create a label for the stage in the meiotic cycle that reads “Interphase (Before Meiosis)” and position the label next to the nuclear membrane.
  • Take a photo of the labeled model with a digital camera or smart-phone. This image will be used later for answering the Laboratory Questions and can also be used for future test review.
  • Save the pieces of thread and the chromosome structures for the next activity.

Individual chromosomes would not be visible during interphase in a cell viewed under a microscope because the chromosomes are so long and thin. Only when condensed are the chromosomes visible under the microscope, assuming their characteristic “X” shape.

Prophase I:
  • Move the two centrioles so that they are on opposite sides of the nucleus, approximately 5 cm inside the nuclear membrane.
  • Use a piece of transparent tape to secure each centriole to the work surface so that the opening of the bead faces the area that was the nucleus.
  • Break down the nuclear membrane by pulling pieces of tape from the work surface. If possible, keep the tape in strips on the side of the workspace to reuse later as a new nuclear membrane.
  • Arrange the chromosomes with arms outstretched to demonstrate that they are condensed. Then, twist the arms of sister chromatids together.
  • Bring the homologous chromosomes together while the arms of each chromosome are still twisted. The red chromosome (the two red chromatids) will be connected to the yellow chromosome (the two yellow chromatids) at the centromeres.
  • To simulate , detach a few beads from one homologous chromosome and exchange them in the corresponding location with its homologous pair. The traded sections must be an equal number of beads. The beads will remain in their new positions for the rest of this activity.
  • Create a label for the stage in the meiotic cycle that reads “Meiosis Prophase I” and take a photo of the labeled model.

Metaphase I:
  • Cut four lengths of thread, each approximately 1 meter long. Set two aside for later. Using two pieces of thread, tie a loop around each pair of magnetic centromeres. When finished, each chromosome (consisting of two chromatids) should have a length of thread tied to it.
  • Pass one loose end of the thread through one of the centrioles, and pass the other loose end through the other centriole.
  • Position the chromosomes near the midpoint between the centrioles and at a right angle to the threads, as shown in .
  • Create a label for the stage in the meiotic cycle and take a photo of the labeled model.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: Homologous pairs side-by-side at the equator

pageData.text: Figure 8 does not reflect the crossing over step and therefore will differ slightly from the models.

Anaphase I:
  • Gently pull the ends of the threads through the centrioles so that the homologous chromosomes separate and move toward opposite sides of the cell and adjacent to a centriole.
  • Create a label for this stage in the meiotic cycle, and take a photo of the labeled model.

Telophase I:
  • Remove the thread from each chromosome and set aside the threads. Save the pieces of thread for the next activity.
  • To represent decondensing, pile the chromosomes beside their closest centriole.
  • Use the masking tape previously set aside, along with additional masking tape, to create a new nuclear membrane around each set of chromosomes. Each new nuclear membrane should be about the same size as the original. This concludes the modeling of meiosis I.
  • Create a label for this stage in the meiotic cycle, and take a photo of the labeled model.
  • Cytokinesis will occur at the same time as telophase. Each of the two cells has a haploid set of chromosomes, but these are still sister chromatids.
Prophase II:
Note that two cells are now being modeled. Model the same event in each cell, side-by-side.

• Add two more centrioles.
  • Move each pair of centrioles so that they are on opposite sides of the nucleus, approximately 20 cm from the outer edge of the nuclear membrane.
  • Use a piece of transparent tape to secure each centriole to the work surface so that the opening of the bead faces the area that was the nucleus of the cell.
  • Break down the nuclear membranes by pulling pieces of tape from the work surface. If possible, keep the masking tape in strips on the side of the workspace to reuse later as a new nuclear membrane.
  • Arrange the chromosomes with arms outstretched to demonstrate that they are condensed. Then, twist the arms of sister chromatids together.
  • Create a label for this stage in the meiotic cycle, and take a photo of the labeled model.
  • Cytokinesis will occur at the same time as telophase. Each of the two cells has a haploid set of chromosomes, but these are still sister chromatids.

The goal of meiosis is to create a haploid gamete cell; therefore there is a very brief “interphase II” separating meiosis I and meiosis II. This stage exists only to reform structures dissolved in telophase I and not to replicate DNA.

Metaphase II:
  • Using four pieces of thread, tie a loop around each magnetic centromere. When finished, each chromatid should have a length of thread tied to it.
  • Pass one of the loose ends of the thread through one of the centrioles, and pass the other loose end through the remaining centriole.
  • Position the chromosome near the midpoint between the centrioles and at a right angle to the threads, as shown in .
  • Create a label for this stage in the meiotic cycle, and take a photo of the labeled model.

pageData.text:
Anaphase II:
  • Gently pull the ends of the threads through the centrioles so that the sister chromatids separate and move toward opposite sides of the cell.
  • Create a label for this stage in the meiotic cycle, and take a photo of the labeled model.

Telophase II:
  • Remove the thread from each chromosome and set it aside.

typeBefore.title: Chromosome Misregulation
typeBefore.text: In this activity, two mechanisms of nondisjunction during meiosis are modeled. Then, the progression of events when an <button class='glossary-text'>aneuploid</button> gamete fuses with another gamete in fertilization preparing to begin mitosis is observed.

typeBefore.title:
A
  Nondisjunction of Homologous Chromosomes During Meiosis I Procedure (10 steps)
typeBefore.text: Using the materials from the Meiosis Activity, build two chromosomes, one of each color. Make sure that each chromosome is made of two sister chromatids. Each sister chromatid should be made of 20 beads with a magnetic <button class='glossary-text'>centromere</button> in the center.

pageData.text:
Interphase (normal):
  • Position two plastic outside the nuclear membrane ring.
  • Place the chromosomes in a pile inside the nuclear membrane.

Prophase I (normal):
  • Move the centrioles so that they are on opposite sides of the nucleus, approximately 20 cm from the outer edge of the nuclear membrane.
  • Use a piece of transparent tape to secure each centriole to the work surface so that the opening of the bead faces the area that was the nucleus.
  • Break down the nuclear membrane by pulling pieces of tape from the work surface. If possible, keep the tape in strips on the side of the workspace to reuse later as a new nuclear membrane.
  • Arrange the chromosomes with arms outstretched to demonstrate that they are condensed. Then, twist the arms of sister chromatids together.
  • Bring the homologous chromosomes together while the arms of each chromosome are still twisted. Normally, would occur at this point, but for this modeling activity, crossing-over will be skipped to make it is easier to track each chromosome.

Metaphase I (misregulation occurs):
  • Using a piece of thread, tie one loop around both pairs of magnetic centromeres.
  • Pass the loose end of the thread through one centriole.
  • Position the chromosomes near the midpoint between the centrioles and at a right angle to the thread.

Anaphase I (misregulation continues): Gently pull the ends of the thread through the centriole. The microtubules (thread) from one side did not successfully attach to one of the pairs, or the centromeres did not detach from the homologous pairs. The cause is not entirely clear, but the result is that both homologous pairs end up on the same side of the cell.

Telophase I (misregulation continues):
  • Remove the thread from the chromosomes and set it aside.
  • To represent decondensing, pile the chromosomes beside their closest centriole.
  • Cytokinesis will occur at the same time as telophase. Due to the misregulation, one cell has an extra chromosome, and one cell lacks a chromosome.

Remember that this model only describes the behavior of one homologous chromosome pair. Imagine there are other homologous chromosomes that were successfully separated. Use the masking tape previously set aside, along with additional masking tape, to create a new nuclear membrane around the area where a new nuclear membrane would form. Because of the misregulation, one membrane will have both homologous chromosomes (that is, 4 chromatids) and the other membrane will have no chromosomes at all. In a typical cell there are other chromosomes not represented by this model; therefore, think of the empty membrane as missing a chromosome, rather than lacking chromosomes completely.

Prophase II (misregulation continues):
  • Add two more centrioles.
  • Move each centriole so that they are on opposite sides of the nucleus, approximately 20 cm from the outer edge of the nuclear membrane.
  • Use a piece of transparent tape to secure each centriole to the work surface so that the opening of the bead faces the area that was the nucleus of the cell.
  • Break down the nuclear membranes by pulling pieces of tape from the work surface.
  • Arrange the chromosomes with arms outstretched to demonstrate that they are condensed.

Metaphase II (misregulation continues): The chromosomes line up along the equator of each cell. The homologous pair should be separated.
  • Using four pieces of thread, tie a loop around each magnetic centromere. When finished, each chromatid should have a long thread tied to it.
  • For each chromosome, thread one loose end of the thread through one of the centrioles and the other loose end through the opposite centriole.
  • Gently pull the threads to position the chromosomes near the midpoint between the centrioles and at a right angle to the threads. Sister chromatids are still attached.

Anaphase II (misregulation continues): Microtubules pull sister chromatids toward opposite sides of the cell. Each chromatid is now properly referred to as a chromosome. Gently pull the ends of the threads through the centrioles so that the sister chromatids separate and move toward opposite sides of the cell until they are adjacent to the centrioles.

Telophase II (misregulation continues): A visible nuclear membrane begins to form around each set of chromosomes. The chromosomes decondense, and the microtubules break down.
  • Remove the thread from each chromosome and set it aside.
  • To represent decondensing, pile the chromosomes beside their closest centriole.
  • Use the masking tape previously set aside, along with additional masking tape, to create a new nuclear membrane around each of the four nuclei.

Two of the nuclei will have no chromosomes, and the other two will have two chromosomes each—one red and one yellow. Another way of describing this is that two cells have n + 1 chromosomes, and two have n – 1 chromosomes.

Using the materials from the Meiosis Activity, build two chromosomes. Each chromatid should be made of 20 beads of the same color with a magnetic centromere in the center. Build a nuclear membrane out of masking tape, and place the two chromosomes inside the nuclear membrane.

typeBefore.title:
B
  Nondisjunction of Sister Chromatids During Meiosis II Procedure (10 steps)

pageData.text:
Interphase (normal):
  • Position plastic centrioles, one on each side 20 cm outside the nuclear membrane ring.
  • Place the chromosomes in a pile inside the nuclear membrane.

Prophase I (normal):
  • Move the centrioles so that they are on opposite sides of the nucleus, approximately 20 cm from the edge of the nuclear membrane.
  • Use a piece of transparent tape to secure each centriole to the work surface so that the opening of one of the beads of each pair faces the area that was the nucleus.
  • Break down the nuclear membrane by pulling pieces of tape from the work surface. If possible, keep the tape in strips on the side of the workspace to reuse it later as a new nuclear membrane.
  • Arrange the chromosomes with arms outstretched to demonstrate that they are condensed. Then, twist the arms of sister chromatids together.
  • Bring the homologous chromosomes together while the arms of each chromosome are still twisted. Normally, crossing-over would occur at this point, but is omitted for this modeling activity, so it is easier to keep track of each chromosome.

Metaphase I (normal):
  • Using a piece of thread, tie a loop around each pair of magnetic centromeres. The red chromatids are together and the yellow chromatids are together.
  • Pass the loose ends of the thread through the centrioles. The thread from the red chromosome will be passed through one centriole and the thread from the yellow chromosome will be passed through the opposite centriole.
  • Position the chromosomes near the midpoint between the centrioles and at a right angle to the thread.
Anaphase I (normal): Gently pull the ends of the thread through the centrioles so that the homologous pairs separate and move toward opposite sides of the cell.

Teleophase I (normal):
  • Remove the thread from the chromosomes and set it aside.
  • To represent decondensing, pile the chromosomes beside their closest centriole.
  • Cytokinesis will occur at the same time as telophase. The model now represents two cells, each possessing one chromosome.

Remember that this model only describes the behavior of one homologous pair of chromosomes. Use the masking tape set aside, along with additional masking tape, to create a new nuclear membrane in the area where a new nuclear membrane normally would form.

Prophase II (normal):
  • Add two more centrioles.
  • Move each centriole so that they are on opposite sides of the nucleus, approximately 20 cm from the outside edge of the nuclear membrane.
  • Use a piece of transparent tape to secure each centriole to the work surface so that the opening of the bead faces the area that was the nucleus of the cell.
  • Break down the nuclear membranes by pulling pieces of tape from the work surface.
  • Arrange the chromosomes with arms outstretched to demonstrate that they are condensed.

Metaphase II (misregulation occurs):
  • Using four pieces of thread, tie a loop around each magnetic centromere. When finished, each chromatid should have a length of thread tied to it.
  • For one cell, pass the loose end of a thread through one of the centrioles. Thread the other loose end through the opposite centriole. Demonstrate misregulation in the second cell by only connecting one thread to a centriole. Leave the other thread unattached.
  • Position the chromosomes near the midpoint between the centrioles and at a right angle to the threads.

Anaphase II (misregulation continues): For one cell, gently pull the ends of the threads through the centrioles so that the sister chromatids separate and move toward opposite sides of the cell. Demonstrate misregulation in the second cell by only pulling the thread attached to the centriole, leaving the sister chromatids attached.

Telophase II (misregulation continues):
  • Remove the thread from each chromosome and set it aside.
  • To represent decondensing, pile the chromosomes beside their closest centriole.
  • Use the masking tape previously set aside, along with additional masking tape, to create a new nuclear membrane around each of the four nuclei.
Two of the nuclei will have one chromosome each (n). One will have two chromosomes (n + 1), and one will have no chromosomes (n – 1).

A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1 you will model mitosis by building a homologous chromosome pair and a nuclear membrane. Then, model a cell in interphase, prophase, metaphase, anaphase, and telophase. In Activity 2 you will model meiosis by building a nuclear membrane. Then, model a cell in interphase, prophase I, metaphase I, anaphase I, and telophase I. Next, continue modeling the cell in prophase II, metaphase II, anaphase II, and telophase II. In Activity 3 you will model chromosome mutations by building a nuclear membrane, then modeling meiosis with misregulation in metaphase I. Next, model meiosis with misregulation in metaphase II. Finally, compare each type of nondisjunction.

data.title: Aneuploid
data.content: Describes a cell with an unusual number of chromosomes

data.title: Centrioles
data.content: Tubular structures in animal cellsl that are located on opposite sides of the cell and form spindle fibers during cell division

data.title: Centromere
data.content: A region of DNA where a protein complex (kinetochore) is assembled to bind two chromatids together

data.title: Crossing-over
data.content: The process of trading DNA between non-sister chromatids of a homologous pair during prophase I of meiosis

data.title: G<sub>1</sub> checkpoint
data.content: An interphase checkpoint during which proteins check for DNA damage

data.title: G<sub>1</sub>-phase
data.content: One of the three sub-phases of interphase characterized by cell growth and the synthesis of mRNA and proteins; also called gap phase I

data.title: G<sub>2</sub> checkpoint
data.content: An interphase checkpoint during which replicated DNA is checked for errors and the quantity of proteins is monitored

data.title: G<sub>2</sub>-phase
data.content: One of the three sub-phases of interphase characterized by the synthesis of proteins necessary for chromosome sorting and cell division; also called gap phase II

data.title: Metaphase checkpoint
data.content: The final checkpoint of mitotic cell division; it ensures that the spindle apparatus is connected correctly and, if it is not, causes mitosis to stop until corrections are made

data.title: M-phase
data.content: The process of somatic cell division into 2 daughter cells identical to the parent cell; also called mitosis

data.title: Ploidy
data.content: The number of chromosomes in a cell

data.title: Restriction point
data.content: A checkpoint during cell division during which the cell ensures it is ready to proceed to the next phase of division

data.title: S-phase
data.content: One of the three sub-phases of interphase characterized by DNA replication into identical sister chromatids

data.title: Synapsis
data.content: The process of microtubules pulling homologs together to form a bivalent (tetrad) during prophase I of meiosis
